review.title: Qualitative shape representation based on the qualitative relative direction and distance calculus eOPRAm
review.abstract: This document serves as a brief technical report, detailing the processes used to represent and reconstruct simplified polygons using qualitative spatial descriptions, as defined by the eOPRAm qualitative spatial calculus.

metadata.title: Qualitative shape representation based on the qualitative relative direction and distance calculus eOPRAm

sections.heading: 2 Generating Qualitative Descriptions
sections.text: The aim of this section is to describe the process of generating a qualitative representation of the eOPRAm from simple polyline data. Firstly, a brief priming of the eOPRAm calculation itself. 2.1 The eOPRAm calculation [15] exists as an extension of the OPRAm calculation. Under OPRAm, the point objects are extended by a local reference direction to create "oriented points" or O-points. Using these local reference directions, together with a series of binary relationships, one can express the idea of a relative direction between the O-points. The OPRAm calculation also includes a granularity parameter m that defines the resolution of these relative directions by dividing the plane into 4m sectors.The eOPRAm calculation expands the OPRAm calculation by adding the concept of relative distance to the O-points and yields eo-points.

sections.heading: 2.2.1 Qualitative Directions
sections.text: To calculate the pairs of qualitative direction matrix, one must first find the quantitative anti-clockwise rotation angle between each pair of joined edges or ordered triangular angles. In view of two edges v1 and v2 sharing a common vertex, the positive (anti-clockwise) rotation angle β is defined as: β = arctan2 (vy2, vx2) − arctan2 (vy1, vx1) β = {β if β 0 β + 2π if β < 0 (1) A sketch of the process used to generate all possible linked triangular angles and calculate their rotation angles is shown below. − Algorithm 1 Generating Pairwise Turn AnglesInput: Simple polygon of n n n circles, p0 to pn − 1O blank n matrix for i,.

sections.heading: 2.2.2 Qualitative Distances
sections.text: The next step in creating our qualitative eOPRAm description is to translate the absolute distances between adjacent nodes into qualitative reference distances. As with the instructions, the eOPRAm reference distances are calculated by dividing a plane into 2 m sections and assigning quantitative values to a qualitative representation. Qualitative distances are calculated by comparing the length of each edge with the length of the previous edge as a "control length." Under eOPRAm, a control length is used to convert a series of distance ratios into a series of qualitative distances. The sequence of distance ratios is defined by the granularity parameter m, which is used to indicate that there are 2 m partitions of these ratios: the first half are marked distances ≤ 2 m marked at even distances of 0 m, 2 m, 2 m m m m − 1 m, 1. The second half of the distances sent again >.

sections.heading: 3 Initial Reconstruction and Refinement
sections.text: The first step of the reconstruction process is simply to "trace" the hull of the eOPRAm descriptions generated in 2.2.1 and 2.2.2. First, we turn the hull list of eOPRAm direction intervals of eq. 3 back to rotation angles (by multiplying each value by the angular resolution, eq. 4) and use the qualitative distances generated in algorithm 2 as edge lengths to place the vertices. This process gives us a rough representation that we will refine in the next steps.

sections.heading: 3.1 Initial Reconstruction
sections.text: In the current implementation, the input polyline xy0 (p0) is used to help orient and anchor our reconstructed polyline. Traceability of the eOPRAm hull is done as follows: Algorithm 4 Tracing the Qualitative Hull of an n-side PolygonT ← List of n eOPRAm statements back to the angle D ← List of n eOPRAm qualitative edge lengths P ← empty list to hold reconstructed points P0 ← Input Polygon's p0. Using the input polygon's p0 as our p0for i ← 0,. n do pi + 1 ← nextXY (pi, Di, Ti) end forreturn P of points returned by nextXYThe nextXY method simply returns the next x, y coordinates using the standard vector equations of: xn + 1 = xn identical polygonal lines that have polygynous + (sin) distance.

sections.heading: 3.2 Refinement
sections.text: In most cases, the initial reconstruction results in a closure that is not closed and corresponds only to the qualitative hull descriptors.The goal of the reconstruction stage is twofold: • to achieve closure and • to minimize the difference between the initial polar line paired with the eOPRAm directional matrix and the reconstructed polar line paired with the eOPRAm directional matrix if the difference between the two targets is kept in mind. Successor polylines are created by applying a series of four adjustments to each of the reconstructed polar lines (minus the endpoints): • to lengthen the outgoing edge length • to increase the angle of rotation and • to decrease the angle of rotation. Successor polylines are only passed on to the next steps if: the resulting polar line does not increase the closing gap or the eOPRAm directional difference.

sections.heading: 4 Preliminary Results
sections.text: With an eOPRAm granularity of m = 8, all polylines of the sample can be successfully translated into qualitative eOPRA8 descriptions and reassembled into roughly similar polylines that achieve both closure and 0-difference descriptions of the shell of eOPRA8, with differences in the pairwise direction of nearly 0 eOPRA8. While the refimenent process allows arbitrarily up to 100 iterations and up to 20 adjustment refinements, most samples tested reach closure well before these limits. Here are three sample results using input polylines with 7, 9 and 10 corners. For each input polyline of the sample, three shapes are shown: from left to right, the input polyline, the initial reconstruction and the final adjusted polyline. In all the following cases, the input polylines and the final polylines exhibit identical OPRA8 descriptions.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion and Outlook
sections.text: In order to test for this cognitive appropriateness, qualitative mold representation must be reversible.With our approach, we can take qualitative mold representation and generate prototypical specific shapes that match the abstract description.Our work, as described in this report, is the first-ever QSR-based mold description that is capable of generating prototypical shapes based on abstract QSR-based representation.The results presented in this report are produced by a small group of python programs designed to perform the de- and reconstruction tasks.Future work will include conducting empirical studies with human subjects to test the cognitive appropriateness of our new qualitative mold representation.

referenceMentions.context: Qualitative spatial reasoning (QSR) abstracts metrical details of the physical world and enables computers to make predictions about spatial relations even when precise quantitative information is unavailable [3].

A complementary view from the cognitive perspective is that the qualitative method compares features within the object domain rather than by measuring them in terms of some artificial external scale [4].

The two main directions in QSR are topological reasoning about regions [17], [19], [20] and positional reasoning about point configurations, like reasoning about orientation and distance [4], [2], [22], [8].

These approaches represent qualitative shape by listing the relative positions of the adjacent vertices of polygons enumerating the outline of the polygon [5].

Based on the recent work by Moratz and Wallgrüen [15] there is a candidate for a finer resolution positional QSR calculus called eOPRAm which is suited to describe outlines of polygons on different levels of granularity.
Such experiments became a standard tool in QSR [9].
